thread.title: Two JetBlue women passengers brawl with pepper spray, razorTravelandtourworld.com
thread.title_full: Two JetBlue women passengers brawl with pepper spray, razorTravelandtourworld.com

author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Two JetBlue women passengers brawl with pepper spray, razorTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Two JetBlue women passengers brawl with pepper spray, razor Published on : Thursday, August 27, 2015
Brouhaha broke out on a JetBlue Flight 690 as it arrived to its gate at New York JFK on Wednesday when two women on the flight allegedly entered into a brawl leaving a good Samaritan slashed and others sickened by pepper spray, according to reports from New York City media.
In a statement to Today in the Sky, JetBlue confirmed the incident saying: “On August 26, a customer disagreement occurred shortly after flight 960 arrived at New York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport from Kingston, Jamaica. Law enforcement were called and met the aircraft.”
The New York Post says the whole untoward incident began when 61-year-old passenger Jean Ballentine of Brooklyn allegedly tried to get from her window seat to the aisle by climbing over 52-year-old Mary Cannady of Linden.
To this, Cannady reacted by pushing Ballentine away who in turn punched Cannady in the face, reports The New York Daily News as per an account of the incident from Port Authority spokesman Joe Pentangelo.
A good Samaritan tried to intervene when Ballentine lashed out with an eyebrow razor, cutting the man’s elbow.
At that point, Cannady got a small can of pepper spray from her pocketbook and squirted the eye-and-skin irritant onto Ballentine, Newsday of Long Island writes quoting Pentangelo. Several passengers were treated for breathing difficulties, Pentangelo tells the Daily News.
The flight was coming from Kingston, Jamaica, and had landed at JFK at around 8:45 a.m. ET arriving to the gate when the ruckus broke out.
The Post adds “it was unclear how the two women were able to board the plane in Kingston with the bladed instrument and the spray.”
JetBlue notes to the newspaper that security screenings in Kingston, where the flight originated, are conducted by the Jamaican Civil Aviation Authority.
According to The Associated Press, the women were arrested and now face a variety of charges. Ballentine’s charges include assault and weapons charges while Cannady was arrested for possessing pepper spray, authorities tell AP.
